Name: Expanding the availability of food vendor permits, creating an office of street vendor enforcement, and establishing a street vendor advisory board
Title: A Local Law to amend the New York city charter and the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to expanding the availability of food vendor permits, creating an office of street vendor enforcement, and establishing a street vendor advisory board
Summary:
This bill would gradually expand the number of permits to vend food on the streets and sidewalks of New York City. Three hundred new permits, now referred to as supervisory licenses, would be issued each year beginning in 2019 until 2028. Thirty additional supervisory licenses would be issued each year over the same period to veterans, amounting to 10% of the total number. In 2021, the Commissioner of the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene would evaluate the impact of the 990 supervisory licenses issued by that time and whether the continued issuance of such licenses are in the best interest of the city. Depending on the findings of the study, the Commissioner has the discretion to discontinue or reduce the number of supervisory licenses issued in subsequent years.  

To address the illegal transfer of permits, the new supervisory licenses requires at least one supervisory licensee to be present at a pushcart at all times. This new requirement will not be applied to existing permits. The bill will also increase the fees for all permits and supervisory licenses.

Importantly, the bill creates a new dedicated vending law enforcement unit, which would exclusively enforce vending laws. It would focus first on those areas of the City with known vending enforcement challenges, and move to all areas as compliance improves. 

It would also create a street vendor advisory board, which will include vendors, brick and mortar small businesses, representatives from community groups, labor unions, property owners, and city agencies, to examine the rules for duplicative, unclear, or unnecessary provisions.

Be it enacted by the Council as follows:
      Section 1. Chapter 1 of the New York city charter is amended by adding a new section 13-e to read as follows:
	� 13-e Office of Street Vendor Enforcement. There shall be an office of street vendor enforcement, which shall consist of enforcement agents who are specially trained in local laws and rules related to vending on the streets and sidewalks of the city of New York. The office of street vendor enforcement shall be fully operational on or before September 1, 2018 and shall commence enforcement activities on or before such date. Such enforcement activities shall, at a minimum, include a sufficient number of street patrols to inspect or examine the vending activities  of at least 75 percent of applicable permitees or licensees on an annual basis. For the purposes of this section, the term "applicable permitees or licensees" means persons issued full-term or temporary permits pursuant to section 17-307 of the code, or persons issued licenses to vend pursuant to sections 17-307 or 17-307.1 of the code, or licenses issued pursuant to section 20-456 of the code. The mayor may establish such office in the executive office of the mayor, within any other office in the executive office of the mayor, or within any department, the head of which is appointed by the mayor. Such office shall have the power and duty to: 
	a. enforce all local laws and rules related to vending on the streets and sidewalks of the city of New York, other than such local laws and rules related to food safety, including, but not limited to, section 16-118, subchapter 2 of chapter 3 of title 17, subchapter 27 of chapter 2 of title 20 and chapter 1 of title 24 of this code; article 89 of the health code; and subchapter AA of chapter 2 of title 6, chapter 6 of title 24 and chapter 1 of title 56 of the rules of the city of New York; 
      b. focus its enforcement efforts on areas including, but not limited to, areas in the designated vending locations pilot program created by the local law that added this section, areas adjacent to retailers that dedicate substantial floor area to the sale of fresh fruits and vegetables, and any other areas identified by the department of transportation as excessively congested and featuring a high level of complaints about vendor activity, if any; 
	c. collaborate with the department of small business services to provide training and education to all street vendors on all applicable local laws and regulations, with a focus on areas including, but not limited to, areas in the designated vending locations pilot program created by the local law that added this section, as well as other areas identified by the department of transportation as excessively congested and featuring a high level of compaints about vendor activity, if any; and
      d. engage in such other activities related to enforcement of laws related to vending on the streets and sidewalks of the city of New York, or related to improving compliance with such laws, as may be designated by the mayor. For the purposes of this section, "excessively congested" areas include, but are not limited to, areas where pedestrian volume regularly approaches or exceeds the capacity of the sidewalk.

      � 17-307.1 Supervisory Licenses 
      a. Eligibility for supervisory license. 
      1. Any natural person may apply for a supervisory license who satisfies the qualifications described in at least one of the following categories:
      (a) such person has been on a waiting list for a full-term permit or temporary permit pursuant to this subchapter since October 1, 2011 and remains on such list as of the date of issuance;
      (b) such person has held a food vendor license continuously since March 1, 2014; or
      (c) such person has been on a waiting list for a full-term permit or temporary permit pursuant to this subchapter as of, or earlier than, September 30 , 2011 and remains on such list as of the date of issuance.
      2. Any natural person may apply for a supervisory license who has been issued a permit, on or after June 1, 2019, pursuant to paragraphs 2 or 3 of subdivision b, or subdivision f, of section 17-307.
      b. Issuance of supervisory licenses. 
      1. For persons described in paragraph 1 of subdivision a, the department shall make available up to 300 supervisory licenses on the following dates:
      (a) On June 1 of each calendar year beginning in 2019 until June 1, 2021;
      (b) On June 1 of each calendar year beginning in 2022 until June 1, 2025; and
      (c) On June 1 of each calendar beginning in 2026 until June 1, 2028.
      (d) If more than 300 persons apply by June 1 of any such calendar year, such licenses shall be distributed in the order of priority listed in paragraph 1 of subdivision a. To the extent the number of persons that apply for such licenses exceeds the number of available supervisory licenses, the distribution required by this paragraph shall be determined by lottery.
      2. For persons described in paragraph 3 of subdivision b of section 17-307, the department shall make available up to 30 supervisory licenses on the following dates:
      (a) On June 1 of each calendar year beginning in 2019 until June 1, 2021;
      (b) On June 1 of each calendar year beginning in 2022 until June 1, 2025; and
      (c) On June 1 of each calendar beginning in 2026 until June 1, 2028.
      (d) If more than 30 persons apply by June 1 of any such calendar year, such  licenses shall be determined by lottery.
      3.  The department shall not issue a supervisory license to any person who at the time of application had a permit issued pursuant to subdivision b or f of section 17-307 revoked or suspended or who is not fit and able to conduct, maintain or operate a food vending business.
      4.  The department shall not issue a supervisory license to any person who is a minor.
      5.  Any supervisory license issued pursuant to this section shall include, at minimum, the full name and address of the licensee.
      6.  No person shall be issued more than one supervisory license.
      7. Any supervisory license issued pursuant to this section shall be valid for two years unless suspended or revoked.
      c. Issuance of permit. Notwithstanding the numerical limitations on the number of full-term permits described in paragraphs 2 and 3 of subdivision b of section 17-307, the department shall make available a full-term or temporary permit to any natural person holding a supervisory license pursuant to this section, provided that such person meets all other requirements for issuance of such permit.
      d. Regulation of supervisory licenses. 
      1. Any vehicle or pushcart that has a decal issued by the department, which has been obtained by a person issued a permit on or after June 1, 2019, shall not be operated without the presence of a supervisory licensee. 
      2. A person issued a supervisory license is authorized to vend food from any vehicle or pushcart that has a decal issued by the department.
      e. The department is authorized to promulgate any rules necessary to implement the provisions of this section.

The street vendor advisory board shall review and evaluate all state and local laws and rules related to street vendors, including placement restrictions such as the minimum distance of 20 feet from any building entrance or exit, and the process for obtaining a street vendor license or permit pursuant to titles 17 and 20 of the administrative code. In conducting such review and evaluation the board shall consider whether such laws and rules should be clarified, are overly burdensome, or are duplicative. On or before January 1, 2019, the board shall submit to the speaker of the council and the mayor a report containing the board's recommendations in relation to amendments to local laws and/or rules based on such review and evaluation and the basis for each recommendation. Such report shall also include recommendations for the creation of designated community spaces where street vendors can congregate to vend, including specific recommendations concerning appropriate locations for food trucks.
	� 28. The department of transportation shall operate a designated vending locations pilot program. Such pilot program shall, no later than June 1, 2018, identify at least five areas in the city that contain a high level of vendor activity and generate a high number of vending-related complaints. The boundaries of such areas shall be posted on such department's website and may be modified at any time. 
      Until June 1, 2020, the department of transportation may, after consultation with affected community boards and business improvement districts, waive or modify restrictions on the placement of food and general vendors contained in sections 17-315 and 20-465 in such areas. Modifications to restrictions made pursuant to this section shall not result in a net decrease of more than twenty percent in permissible vending areas in any area in the designated vending locations pilot program. The department of transportation shall issue a report to the mayor and council on or before October 1, 2020 on the results of any such waivers or modifications.
      � 29. Nothing in this local law limits the authority of any agency granted elsewhere in law to enforce any law or rule.
      � 30. The commissioners of health and mental hygiene and consumer affairs, and the board of health, may promulgate rules as may be necessary for the purposes of carrying out the provisions of this local law.
      � 31. Sections one, eleven, twelve, and nineteen of this local law take effect 90 days after they become law. Sections two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, ten, thirteen, eighteen, twenty, twenty-five, twenty-seven, twenty-eight, twenty-nine and thirty of this local law take effect immediately. Sections fourteen, fifteen, sixteen, twenty-two, twenty-three and twenty-four of this local law take effect 30 days after they become law. Section twenty-seven expires and shall be deemed repealed on January 1, 2020. Section twenty-one of this local law takes effect 180 days after it becomes law. Section seventeen of this local law takes effect one year after it becomes law. Section twenty-six of this local law takes effect two years after it becomes law.

\pard\ltrpar\noline\nowidctlpar\qj\v ..Title\par
\v0 A Local Law to amend the New York city charter and the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to expanding the availability of food vendor permits, creating an office of street vendor enforcement, and establishing a street vendor advisory board\par
\v ..Body\par
\pard\ltrpar\noline\nowidctlpar\qj\tx3630\v0\tab\par
\pard\ltrpar\noline\nowidctlpar\sl480\slmult1\qj\ul Be it enacted by the Council as follows\ulnone :\par
\pard\ltrpar\fi720\sl480\slmult1\qj Section 1. Chapter 1 of the New York city charter is amended by adding a new section 13-e to read as follows:\ul\par
\pard\ltrpar\sl480\slmult1\qj\ulnone\tab\ul\'a7 13-e Office of Street Vendor Enforcement. There shall be an office of street vendor enforcement, which shall consist of enforcement agents who are specially trained in local laws and rules related to vending on the streets and sidewalks of the city of New York. The office of street vendor enforcement shall be fully operational on or before September 1, 2018 and shall commence enforcement activities on or before such date. Such enforcement activities shall, at a minimum, include a sufficient number of street patrols to inspect or examine the vending activities  of at least 75 percent of applicable permitees or licensees on an annual basis. For the purposes of this section, the term \ldblquote applicable permitees or licensees\rdblquote  means persons issued full-term or temporary permits pursuant to section 17-307 of the code, or persons issued licenses to vend pursuant to sections 17-307 or 17-307.1 of the code, or licenses issued pursuant to section 20-456 of the code. The mayor may establish such office in the executive office of the mayor, within any other office in the executive office of the mayor, or within any department, the head of which is appointed by the mayor. Such office shall have the power and duty to: \par
\ulnone\tab\ul a. enforce all local laws and rules related to vending on the streets and sidewalks of the city of New York, other than such local laws and rules related to food safety, including, but not limited to, section 16-118, subchapter 2 of chapter 3 of title 17, subchapter 27 of chapter 2 of title 20 and chapter 1 of title 24 of this code; article 89 of the health code; and subchapter AA of chapter 2 of title 6, chapter 6 of title 24 and chapter 1 of title 56 of the rules of the city of New York; \par
\pard\ltrpar\fi720\sl480\slmult1\qj b. focus its enforcement efforts on areas including, but not limited to, areas in the designated vending locations pilot program created by the local law that added this section, areas adjacent to retailers that dedicate substantial floor area to the sale of fresh fruits and vegetables, and any other areas identified by the department of transportation as excessively congested and featuring a high level of complaints about vendor activity, if any; \par
\pard\ltrpar\sl480\slmult1\qj\ulnone\tab\ul c. collaborate with the department of small business services to provide training and education to all street vendors on all applicable local laws and regulations, with a focus on areas including, but not limited to, areas in the designated vending locations pilot program created by the local law that added this section, as well as other areas identified by the department of transportation as excessively congested and featuring a high level of compaints about vendor activity, if any; and\par
\pard\ltrpar\fi720\sl480\slmult1\qj d. engage in such other activities related to enforcement of laws related to vending on the streets and sidewalks of the city of New York, or related to improving compliance with such laws, as may be designated by the mayor. For the purposes of this section, \ldblquote excessively congested\rdblquote  areas include, but are not limited to, areas where pedestrian volume regularly approaches or exceeds the capacity of the sidewalk.\par

\ul\'a7 17-307.1 Supervisory Licenses \par
a. Eligibility for supervisory license. \par
1. Any natural person may apply for a supervisory license who satisfies the qualifications described in at least one of the following categories:\par
(a) such person has been on a waiting list for a full-term permit or temporary permit pursuant to this subchapter since October 1, 2011 and remains on such list as of the date of issuance;\par
(b) such person has held a food vendor license continuously since March 1, 2014; or\par
(c) such person has been on a waiting list for a full-term permit or temporary permit pursuant to this subchapter as of, or earlier than, September 30 , 2011 and remains on such list as of the date of issuance.\par
2. Any natural person may apply for a supervisory license who has been issued a permit, on or after June 1, 2019, pursuant to paragraphs 2 or 3 of subdivision b, or subdivision f, of section 17-307.\par
b. Issuance of supervisory licenses. \par
1. For persons described in paragraph 1 of subdivision a, the department shall make available up to 300 supervisory licenses on the following dates:\par
(a) On June 1 of each calendar year beginning in 2019 until June 1, 2021;\par
(b) On June 1 of each calendar year beginning in 2022 until June 1, 2025; and\par
(c) On June 1 of each calendar beginning in 2026 until June 1, 2028.\par
(d) If more than 300 persons apply by June 1 of any such calendar year, such licenses shall be distributed in the order of priority listed in paragraph 1 of subdivision a. To the extent the number of persons that apply for such licenses exceeds the number of available supervisory licenses, the distribution required by this paragraph shall be determined by lottery.\par
2. For persons described in paragraph 3 of subdivision b of section 17-307, the department shall make available up to 30 supervisory licenses on the following dates:\par
(a) On June 1 of each calendar year beginning in 2019 until June 1, 2021;\par
(b) On June 1 of each calendar year beginning in 2022 until June 1, 2025; and\par
(c) On June 1 of each calendar beginning in 2026 until June 1, 2028.\par
(d) If more than 30 persons apply by June 1 of any such calendar year, such  licenses shall be determined by lottery.\par
3.  The department shall not issue a supervisory license to any person who at the time of application had a permit issued pursuant to subdivision b or f of section 17-307 revoked or suspended or who is not fit and able to conduct, maintain or operate a food vending business.\par
4.  The department shall not issue a supervisory license to any person who is a minor.\par
5.  Any supervisory license issued pursuant to this section shall include, at minimum, the full name and address of the licensee.\par
6.  No person shall be issued more than one supervisory license.\par
7. Any supervisory license issued pursuant to this section shall be valid for two years unless suspended or revoked.\par
c. Issuance of permit. Notwithstanding the numerical limitations on the number of full-term permits described in paragraphs 2 and 3 of subdivision b of section 17-307, the department shall make available a full-term or temporary permit to any natural person holding a supervisory license pursuant to this section, provided that such person meets all other requirements for issuance of such permit.\par
d. Regulation of supervisory licenses. \par
1. Any vehicle or pushcart that has a decal issued by the department, which has been obtained by a person issued a permit on or after June 1, 2019, shall not be operated without the presence of a supervisory licensee. \par
2. A person issued a supervisory license is authorized to vend food from any vehicle or pushcart that has a decal issued by the department.\par
e. The department is authorized to promulgate any rules necessary to implement the provisions of this section.\par

\'a7 25. Subchapter 27 of chapter 2 of title 20 of administrative code of the city of New York is amended by adding a new section 20-465.2 to read as follows:\par
\pard\ltrpar\sl480\slmult1\qj\tab\ul\'a7 20-465.2 Street vendor advisory board. a. There is hereby established a street vendor advisory board consisting of the commissioners of the department of consumer affairs, the department of health and mental hygiene, the department of small business services, the department of transportation, and the police department, or their designees, five members appointed by the speaker, one of whom represents street vendors, one of whom represents the small business community, one of whom represents organizations representing workers at retail food stores, one of whom represents property owners and one of whom who represents a community organization, and two members appointed by the mayor, one of whom represents street vendors and one of whom represents the small business community.\par
\ulnone\tab\ul b. In addition to its other duties, the street vendor advisory board shall, prior to May 1 of each year from 2020 through 2028, issue to the speaker of the council a recommendation on whether the department of health and mental hygiene\rquote s authority to issue any or all of the supervisory licenses authorized to be issued by such department should be restricted, expanded, or otherwise altered based on an analysis of the results of the increased number of mobile food vendor permits issued pursuant to the local law that created this section.\par
\pard\ltrpar\fi720\sl480\slmult1\qj\ulnone\'a7 26. Title 24 of the administrative code of the city of New York is amended by adding a new section 24-149.7 to read as follows:\par
\ul\'a7 24-149.7 Commercial under-fired char broiling. \cf1 No person shall operate a commercial \cf0 under-fired \cf1 char broiler on a mobile food vending unit.  \cf0\par
\pard\ltrpar\sl480\slmult1\qj\ulnone\tab\'a7 27. The street vendor advisory board shall review and evaluate all state and local laws and rules related to street vendors, including placement restrictions such as the minimum distance of 20 feet from any building entrance or exit, and the process for obtaining a street vendor license or permit pursuant to titles 17 and 20 of the administrative code. In conducting such review and evaluation the board shall consider whether such laws and rules should be clarified, are overly burdensome, or are duplicative. On or before January 1, 2019, the board shall submit to the speaker of the council and the mayor a report containing the board\rquote s recommendations in relation to amendments to local laws and/or rules based on such review and evaluation and the basis for each recommendation. Such report shall also include recommendations for the creation of designated community spaces where street vendors can congregate to vend, including specific recommendations concerning appropriate locations for food trucks.\par
\tab\'a7 28. The department of transportation shall operate a designated vending locations pilot program. Such pilot program shall, no later than June 1, 2018, identify at least five areas in the city that contain a high level of vendor activity and generate a high number of vending-related complaints. The boundaries of such areas shall be posted on such department\rquote s website and may be modified at any time. \par
\pard\ltrpar\fi720\sl480\slmult1\qj Until June 1, 2020, the department of transportation may, after consultation with affected community boards and business improvement districts, waive or modify restrictions on the placement of food and general vendors contained in sections 17-315 and 20-465 in such areas. Modifications to restrictions made pursuant to this section shall not result in a net decrease of more than twenty percent in permissible vending areas in any area in the designated vending locations pilot program. The department of transportation shall issue a report to the mayor and council on or before October 1, 2020 on the results of any such waivers or modifications.\par
\'a7 29. Nothing in this local law limits the authority of any agency granted elsewhere in law to enforce any law or rule.\par
\'a7 30. The commissioners of health and mental hygiene and consumer affairs, and the board of health, may promulgate rules as may be necessary for the purposes of carrying out the provisions of this local law.\par
\'a7 31. Sections one, eleven, twelve, and nineteen of this local law take effect 90 days after they become law. Sections two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, ten, thirteen, eighteen, twenty, twenty-five, twenty-seven, twenty-eight, twenty-nine and thirty of this local law take effect immediately. Sections fourteen, fifteen, sixteen, twenty-two, twenty-three and twenty-four of this local law take effect 30 days after they become law. Section twenty-seven expires and shall be deemed repealed on January 1, 2020. Section twenty-one of this local law takes effect 180 days after it becomes law. Section seventeen of this local law takes effect one year after it becomes law. Section twenty-six of this local law takes effect two years after it becomes law.\par
